--- "Jim O'Flaherty, Jr." <jim_oflaherty_jr@...>
wrote:
> To your response:
> >Yes right, never connect into an input node.
> 
> I agree with Derek, why not?
> 
> I think Derek is coming from the point of view
> regarding "lateral inhibition" (LI), one of the
> unique neural configurations occuring in biology.  

Actually, I wasn't specifically thinking of lateral
inhibition (there are a number of reasons why you may
want feedback to input nodes), but it's definitely a
good example.

> Is this a pretty good re-representation of the idea
> LI?  And am I on the same track as you here? 
> If I am not, what is your reasons for desiring
> connections back to the input nodes outside the
> scope of LI?

Yeah, we're on the same track. :)

You bring up the utility of input nodes connection to
one another, but one might want a network in which
output values are fed back into input nodes.  Same
with hidden nodes.  Basically, recurrent connections
are ways of holding information in memory, and there
are probably many, many cases in which something held
in the memory of the network may be effective in
adjusting the input into the network.

Derek
